posts.name:
Walter Crosby
Walter Crosby
posts.content:
Top performers aren't just looking for a paycheck - they're searching for an environment that matches their drive.

I've seen it countless times: A star employee gets frustrated watching others coast by with mediocre effort. They don't want to be the only ones pushing for excellence.

The harsh reality? You can't demand what you don't demonstrate. Leadership starts with your own accountability.

 List one way you personally model accountability.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely true! I model accountability by setting clear goals and regularly reflecting on our teams progress to inspire others. #Leadership

posts.name:
Yehia EL HOURI
Yehia EL HOURI
posts.content:
Second chances donâ€™t always guarantee success.

 But they often inspire it.

Iâ€™ll never forget a time early in my career when I made a mistake that left me sleepless for days.

 It wasnâ€™t just a small slip, it impacted my team and derailed a critical deadline.

 I braced for the worst.

Instead, my manager said: "Youâ€™re better than this. Letâ€™s fix it, and make sure it doesnâ€™t happen again."

That second chance shifted something in me.

 I worked harder than ever, not just to fix the issue, but to rebuild trust.

More importantly, it shaped how I lead today.

 Second chances arenâ€™t about ignoring mistakes, theyâ€™re about believing in peopleâ€™s capacity to grow.

When we do that, we donâ€™t just repair situations; we strengthen relationships, foster loyalty, and inspire resilience.

 They build trust: Mistakes donâ€™t define us; how we respond does.
 They inspire loyalty: People never forget who stood by them.
 They spark growth: A second chance often unlocks potential we didnâ€™t know was there.

 Whatâ€™s your perspective? Have you ever given (or received) a second chance that changed the outcome in ways you didnâ€™t expect?

 Letâ€™s share insights below.

posts.name:
David Bradford
David Bradford
posts.content: $500 Billion Investment in AI! Here is the Rest of the Story. The year was 1986. We did the deal that launched Masayoshi Son and Softbank into Mega Success. As a young General Counsel of Novell, one of my first deals was with Mr. Son for the distribution of Novell's NetWare into the Japan market. I remember Mr. Son being a fun guy, full of energy, and wickedly smart. All of this before he became a global figure and the biggest investor in Stargate- the new AI Infrastructure play announced yesterday by Trump and Mr. Son (along with Ellison and Altman). In the 1980s, Mr Son was a budding entrepreneur and wanted to become a Distributor for us. While Novell eventually declined in prominence, Masayoshi Son used the momentum from that early partnership to build SoftBank into a global powerhouse, investing in transformative technologies and startups. The Novell-Son relationship remains a testament to the power of recognizing and capitalizing on emerging technologies ...now like AI!
posts.commentAdded: Incredible journey! Its fascinating to see how early partnerships can shape industry leaders and drive innovation like AI today. ğŸš€

posts.name:
Matthew Buchalski
Matthew Buchalski
posts.content:
You can't change the people around you but you can change the people around you.

Wait, what?

Let me explain:

You canâ€™t change peopleâ€™s attitudes or behaviors, but you can change the people you surround yourself with.

I first heard this quote on a @Lewis Howes podcast years ago, and it stuck with me.

It is one of those hard truths that hits differently depending on the situation, but it always resonates.

As leaders, we are constantly evaluating the people in our sphere.

Can this person grow?

Can I help them improve?

Is their potential worth the time and energy it will take to bring them to where they need to be?

Changing someoneâ€™s beliefs, habits, or behaviors is often more difficult than we anticipate.

It can be a massive investment of time, with no guarantee of success.

Sometimes, the better decision is to part ways and find someone who is already aligned with the needs of the team or the role.

In our personal lives, this idea carries just as much weight.

We have all had relationships where we do not agree with someoneâ€™s work ethic, values, or philosophies.

And while it is tempting to think we can change them, we need to ask ourselves:

1/ Is it worth the effort?
2/ Do I want to try?
3/ Or is it time to find a new group of friends, colleagues, or partners who are better aligned with who I am and what I value?

Here is the reality. You canâ€™t force change on someone who isnâ€™t willing.

But you can change your environment to surround yourself with people who inspire, challenge, and support you.

Whether it is in business or life, the people around you play a huge role in your growth and happiness.

Choose them wisely.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Surrounding ourselves with the right people fosters growth and positivity. Heres to choosing our tribe wisely! ğŸŒŸ

Yeah, There's a big difference between hate and criticism.

Hate in simple words is just noise. These are usually those people who are either jealous of you or are just insecure fellas.

But criticism is different. A good criticism will help you understand what is it that you are doing wrong. You can use it to make yourself better.

So. remember, use criticism to grow and ignore the noise i.e., HATE.

posts.name:
Cory Blumenfeld
Cory Blumenfeld
posts.content:
Apologies can be meaningless.

Hereâ€™s why:

Mistakes? Totally okay.
They help us grow.

Saying sorry is fine the first time.
Maybe even the second.

But when the same mistake keeps happening...
And all you do is apologize (without taking action)...

It becomes meaningless.

Think about it:

You spend hours, days, weeks...
â‡¢ Guiding someone
â‡¢ Teaching them
â‡¢ Cheering them on

Helping them grow, learn, and be better.

And then they turn around and do the exact same thing.

Itâ€™s not a confidence booster.
It doesnâ€™t build trust.

Were they even listening?
Did all that effort go to waste?

Hereâ€™s the truth:

â‡¢ Apologies without action are useless.
â‡¢ Growth is what really matters.

Hereâ€™s what actually works:
â‡¢ Own your mistake.
â‡¢ Learn from it.
â‡¢ Take real action so it doesnâ€™t happen again.

Donâ€™t just say â€œsorryâ€...
Show youâ€™re serious about improving.



---
